case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Ms. Maharashtra Sugar Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1658 of 1968

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1658 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 22, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 83 of 1962

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 22, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 83 of 1962.

facts.text: Reference made by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bench B, Bombay

anchor.surface_text: That Reference was made by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bench B, Bombay.

facts.text: Question referred under s.66 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922: Whether the Department could disallow Rs. 1,26,359/- portion of managing agency commission for assessment year 1957-58

anchor.surface_text: The question of law which was referred for the. opinion of the High Court under s.66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act  is Whether on the facts and in the circumstances -of this case the Department companyld disallow a sum of Rs. 1,26,359/- a portion of the managing agency ,commission paid by the assessee companypany for the ,assessment year 1957-58

facts.text: Assessee is Ms. Maharashtra Sugar Mills Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is M s. Maharashtra Sugar Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Assessment year 1957-58, corresponding accounting year ending 30-9-1956

anchor.surface_text: The companycerned assessment year is 1957-58, the companyresponding account year ending on 30-9-1956.

facts.text: Assessee is a limited company carrying on business of manufacture of sugar from sugar cane

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a Limited Company. it carries on business of manufacture of sugar from.sugar cane.

facts.text: Assessee owns extensive lands in which sugar cane is grown and used for manufacture of sugar in its factory

anchor.surface_text: It owns extensive lands in which sugar cane is grown. The sugar cane grown in these lands is used by the assessee for manufacture of sugar in its factory.

facts.text: Tribunal finding that cultivation of sugar cane and manufacture of sugar constitute one single and indivisible business

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the Tribunal is that 16-M 1245 Sup. Cl/71 the cultivation of sugar cane and the manufacture of sugar by the assessee companystitute one single and indivisible business.

facts.text: Assessee company managed by managing agents paid remuneration per agreement roughly 10 percent of profits

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany is managed by managing agents. The managing agents were paid remuneration in accordance with the agreement entered into between the assessee companypany and the managing agents The managing agentss companymission roughly worked out at 10 percent of the profits of the companypany.

facts.text: Managing agents entitled to commission of Rs. 4,86,228/- for the assessment year

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment year in question the managing agents were entitled to a companymission of Rs. 4,86,228 /6 -.

facts.text: Assessee claimed deduction of Rs. 4,86,228/- under s.10(2)(15) as business expenditure

anchor.surface_text: In its assessment proceedings, the assessee claimed deduction of this sum under s.10 2  15  as an item of expenditure laid out or expended wholly or exclusively for the purpose of its business.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed Rs. 1,26,359/- as relating to managing commission for sugar cane cultivation part

anchor.surface_text: Out of that sum, the Income-tax Officer disallowed a sum of Rs. 1,26,359/- on the ground that the same relates to the companymission of the managing agents for managing the sugar cane cultivation part of the business.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner concurred with Income-tax Officer

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner companycurred with the view taken by the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld assessee's plea for full deduction under s.10(2)(15)

anchor.surface_text: The assessee took up the matter in second appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. The Tribunal upheld the plea of the assessee that the entire sum is deductible under S. 10 2   15 .

facts.text: Tribunal rejected department's contention that rule 23 applies

anchor.surface_text: It also rejected the companytention of the department that on the facts of the case rule 23 of the Rules framed under the Act is applicable.

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered question in favour of assessee agreeing with Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: In the Reference -referred to earlier, the High Court agreeing with the view. taken by the Tribunal answered the question in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Tribunal's finding that cultivation and manufacture constitute one business not challenged

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the Tribunal that the cultivation of sugar cane as well as the manufacture of sugar companystitutes one business is a finding of fact. That finding has number been challenged before us

facts.text: Department contended assessee's business consisted of two parts: cultivation (agricultural, income not taxable) and manufacture, so expenditure on cultivation not deductible

anchor.surface_text: What. was urged on behalf of the department is that the assessees business companysisted of two parts namely  1  cultivation of sugar cane and the manufacture of sugar. The former part being agricultural operation, the income therefrom is number exigible to tax and therefore any expenditure incurred in respect of that activity is number deductable.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court view

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons we agree with the view taken by the High Court.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 23 to the extent material for our present purpose reads 23 1  In the case of Income which is partially agricultural income as defined in section 2 and partially income chargeable to income-tax under the head business in determining that part which is chargeable to income-tax the market value of any agricultural produce which has been raised by the assessee or received by him as rent in kind and which has been utilised as raw material in such business or the sale receipts of which are included in the accounts of the business shall be deducted, and numberfurther deduction shall be made in respect of any expenditure incurred by the assessee as a cultivator or receiver of rent in kind.

anchor.surface_text: Section  2 1  of the Act defines agricultural income. That section reads agricultural income means-  a  any rent or revenue derived from land which is used for agricultural purposes, and is either assessed to land-revenue in the taxable territories or subject to a local rate assessed and companylected by officers of the Government as such  b  any income derived from such land by- agricultural or the performance by a cultivator or receiver of rent in kind of any process ordinarily employed by a. cultivator or receiver of rent-in-kind to render the produce raised or received by him fit to be taken to market, or the sale by a cultivator or receiver of rent-in-kind of the produce raised or received by him, in respect of which numberprocess has been performed other than a process of the nature described in sub-clause  ii .

holdings.text: The Department could not disallow Rs. 1,26,359/- portion of the managing agency commission as the entire commission is deductible under s.10(2)(15) since it was laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the assessee's business, notwithstanding that income from part of the business (cultivation) is not exigible to tax.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 2  says that profits under S. 10 1  in respect of a business should be companyputed after deducting the allowances mentioned therein. One of the allowances allowed is that mentioned in s.10 2  which says that any expenditure laid out or expended wholly

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain and unambiguous mandate of s.10(2)(15); business is single and indivisible per unchallenged Tribunal finding; taxability of income irrelevant to deductibility if expenditure wholly for business.

holdings.text: There is no basis for the contention that only expenditure incurred in respect of business activity giving rise to taxable income can be deducted.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberbasis for this companytention. To find out whether a deduction claimed is permissible under the Act or number, all that we have to do is to examine the relevant provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deductibility governed solely by relevant statutory provisions without equitable considerations; s.10(2)(15) does not condition on taxability of income.

holdings.text: Rule 23 does not apply to permit disallowance or splitting of the managing agency commission.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 23 concerns deduction of market value of agricultural produce and prohibits further deduction for expenditures incurred by assessee as cultivator or receiver of rent-in-kind; managing agency commission not such expenditure; harmonious reading with s.2(1).

holdings.text: Equitable considerations are wholly out of place in construing the provisions of a taxing statute.

precedents.citation: S. A. S.S. Chellappa Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1 5 I.T. P,. 97.

anchor.surface_text: S. A. S.S. Chellappa Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras  1  The facts of that case are, The assessee was carrying on the business of money lending in Burma. For the purpose of that business he was borrowing money from others at a lower rate of interest and advancing loans to his- companystituents at a higher rate. In the companyrse of his business, he was obliged to receive agricultural lands in repayment of his debts from some of his companystituents. In his assessment proceedings he claimed deduction of the interest David by him in respect of his borrowings. Part of the money borrowed by him had been advanced to companystituents who, as mentioned earlier, had made over their agricultural lands to the assessee. The question arose whether the interest paid in respect of the money advanced to those companystituents was deductable in companyputing the profits and gains of the assessee. The High Court held that he was entitled to the deduction claimed and further he was also entitled to deduction in  1  5 I.T. P,. 97.

precedents.case_name: S. A. S.S. Chellappa Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of business is deductible even if part of the business activity leads to non-taxable income like agricultural lands received in repayment of debts.
precedents.cited_holding: Was the capital borrowed for the purpose of the assessee's business? ... The test applied by the learned Chief Justice appears to us to be the correct one.

precedents.citation: Salt and Industries Agencies Ltd., Bombay v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1 18 L.T.R. 58.

anchor.surface_text: We shall next take up the decision of the Bombay High Court in Salt and Industries Agencies Ltd., Bombay v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City  1 . The assessee in that case was a companypany incorporated in Bombay. They were the managing agents of another companypany which was also incorporated in Bombay. The managed companypany had business both in British India as well as in the Indian States. The profits arising from the business activities of the managed companypany in the Indian States was number exigible to tax but yet the assessee claimed that a part of the companymission earned by it being in respect of business carried on outside British India, the same companyld number be companysidered as an income earned in British India. That companytention was rejected by the High Court. In the companyrse of its judgment, the High Court observed It is perfectly true that as far as the parent companypany is companycerned, the profits made at Kandla companyld be said to have arisen and accrued at Kandla, but as far as the managing agents are companycerned, their companymission has numberhing whatever to do with those profits.  1  18 L.T.R. 58.

precedents.case_name: Salt and Industries Agencies Ltd., Bombay v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: Managing agency commission is computed on overall profits of the company and cannot be split based on taxable or non-taxable sources of profits.
precedents.cited_holding: their commission has nothing whatever to do with those profits. Their commission is only concerned with the ultimate determination of all the workings of the company and the finding out whether and what profits has been earned by the company.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. C Parakh Co. India Ltd. 1 29 I.T.R. 661.

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. C Parakh Co. India  Ltd. I. The ratio of that decision bears on the question of law that we are companysidering. The assessee company therein was resident and ordinarily resident in India. It had its head office in Bombay. It maintained a branch at Karachi for purchasing cotton for shipment to Bombay or to export direct to other places. By an agreement, the managing agents of the assessee company were entitled to a remuneration of 20 percent of the annual net profits of the assessee company to ascertain which the result of the trade in all its branches had to be taken into account. The assessee apportioned the managing agency commission and debited the proportionate amount in the respective profit and loss account for the Bombay head office and the Karachi branch. In computing the Pakistan income of the assessee for the purpose of double taxation relief the Income-tax Officer deducted from the income of the Karachi branch the proportionate managing agency commission. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed that order but the Tribunal and the High Court on a reference held that the managing agency commission in its entirety should be debited to the Bombay branch. On appeal this Court held that the entire managing agency commission was liable to be debited against the Indian profits and further assessee company could not be estopped from claiming the benefit of such deduction by reason of the fact that it erroneously allocated a part of it toward the profits earned in Karachi. In the course of its judgment this Court observed Section 10(2)(xv) of the Indian Income-tax Act provides that in computing the profits of a business allowance is to be made for any expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of such business Now the respondent is carrying on  1  29 I.T.R. 661.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. C. Parakh & Co. (India) Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: When an assessee carries on the same business at a number of places, there is only one business; pool profits from all branches and deduct all expenses including managing agency commission before arriving at taxable profits.
precedents.cited_holding: the entire managing agency commission was liable to be debited against the Indian profits ... the respondent is therefore clearly entitled to a deduction of the whole of the commission ... against the Indian profits.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax Madras v. Indian Bank Ltd 1 56 I.T.R. 79.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly we refer to the decision of this Court in Co mission of Income-tax Madras v. Indian Bank Ltd 1 . Therein the respondent, a banking company, in the course of its business, invested a large sum in securities, including securities the interest on which was exempt from tax. Profits and losses on the purchase and sale of such securities were duly taken into account in computing the business income of the respondent. The question for decision was whether the interest paid by the respondent on the amount invested in securities, whose interest was tax free, was deductable from its gross profits. This Court held that interest paid by the respondent on moneys borrowed from its various depositors had to be allowed in its entirety under S. 10(2)(iii) of the Act and there was no warrant for disallowing a proportionate part of the interest referable to money borrowed for the purchase of securities whose interest was tax-free. In the course of the Judgment Subba Rao, J. as he then was observed In our opinion, in construing the Act, we must adhere closely to the language of the Act. ...  1  56 I.T.R. 79.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. Indian Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Deduction under s.10(2)(iii) or (xv) for expenditure wholly and exclusively for business purpose cannot be disallowed proportionately merely because part relates to activity producing non-taxable income; no need to trace to taxable income.
precedents.cited_holding: interest paid ... had to be allowed in its entirety ... there was no warrant for disallowing a proportionate part ... In Section 10(2)(xv), what Parliament requires to be ascertained is whether the expenditure has been laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business.

precedents.citation: Badridas Doga v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 34 I.T.R. 10.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the department reliance was sought to be placed on the decision of this Court in Badridas Doga v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 .
